title: How to Cut Felt

steps.headline: Draw a line or design on a piece of felt with a disappearing ink marker.
steps.description: You can use a ruler or other straight edges to make a line across your felt, draw a line or design freehand, or follow around the edges of a pattern to create a design. A disappearing ink marker will help to ensure that any remaining ink will not be visible on your finished project. You can purchase disappearing ink at a craft supply store. Tip: If you don't have a disappearing ink marker, a piece of chalk will also work. Or, you could use a regular marker and cut inside the lines so you won't have marker on your felt.

steps.headline: Cut along the lines with a small pair of sharp scissors.
steps.description: Make sure that the scissors you use are very sharp. Then, cut along the lines you drew onto the felt to get the desired shape.

steps.headline: Go back over any edges that you need to clean up.
steps.description: After you finish cutting out the felt, check the edges. Look for any uneven or jagged spots and trim them down. Be careful not to cut too much off or your shape may become distorted.

steps.headline: Draw or trace a design onto a piece of paper and cut it out.
steps.description: You can use a premade shape or pattern on paper or draw your own. Once you have your design, cut along the edges of it with a sharp pair of scissors.Tip: You can cut just about any shape you like out of felt. Try cutting out hearts, stars, clovers, cats, dogs, flowers, leaves, gingerbread men, or whatever else you want!

steps.headline: Tape the pattern onto the felt so that the tape overlaps the edges.
steps.description: Use a few pieces of clear packing tape or scotch tape to attach the paper pattern to the felt. The tape will stick to the paper pattern and the felt so it will stay put while you cut. Using tape is a nice alternative to pinning since there is less chance of poking holes in your felt.

steps.headline: Staple the pattern through 2 layers of felt to cut out 2 pieces at once.
steps.description: If you want to cut out 2 pieces of felt using the same pattern at one time, then you can staple the pattern onto 2 layers of felt. You will only need to staple the paper pattern to the felt in 2 to 3 places around the edges to make it stay put. After you cut around the pattern, remove the staples with a staple remover or your fingernails. Make sure to test a small piece of felt first to ensure stapling through it won't damage it.

steps.headline: Cut along the edges of the line or design.
steps.description: Once your paper pattern piece is secured to the felt, use a sharp pair of fabric scissors to cut along the edges. Cut slowly and carefully to ensure that you get even, smooth lines. The paper pattern piece will come off as you cut, so make sure to hold it in place with your thumb until you have cut out the whole thing. If you stapled the paper pattern piece through 2 pieces of felt, remove the staples after you finish cutting out the pieces.

steps.headline: Trace your pattern onto the freezer paper.
steps.description: Dispense a piece of freezer paper large enough for the pattern you want to create. Freezer paper is clear, so you can lay the freezer paper over it with the waxy side facing down. Trace the pattern onto the non-waxy side of the freezer paper. You can also draw a design onto the non-waxy side of the freezer paper. Do not cut out the pattern! Leave the freezer paper intact.

steps.headline: Place the freezer paper onto the felt.
steps.description: Next, lay the freezer paper on top of your felt with the waxy side facing down. Make sure that the edges of the pattern on the freezer paper fit entirely on the felt.

steps.headline: Iron the freezer paper to the felt.
steps.description: Switch on your iron to the lowest setting and let it warm up for about 10 minutes. When it is hot, press it against the freezer paper and move it around the entire pattern using small, circular motions. Do not leave the iron in one place for more than a few seconds. It can shrink wool felt or melt acrylic felt if you leave it in one place for too long.

steps.headline: Cut around the edges of the pattern.
steps.description: Once the pattern is secured to the felt, use a sharp pair of fabric scissors to cut along the lines. Cut slowly and carefully to ensure that you don't end up with any jagged edges. After you finish cutting out the felt pieces, grasp the edge of the freezer paper and peel it off of the felt.Tip: You can save your freezer paper pattern pieces and reuse them up to 5 times!

text: Drawing Lines onto Felt Draw a line or design on a piece of felt with a disappearing ink marker. You can use a ruler or other straight edges to make a line across your felt, draw a line or design freehand, or follow around the edges of a pattern to create a design. A disappearing ink marker will help to ensure that any remaining ink will not be visible on your finished project. You can purchase disappearing ink at a craft supply store. Tip: If you don't have a disappearing ink marker, a piece of chalk will also work. Or, you could use a regular marker and cut inside the lines so you won't have marker on your felt. Cut along the lines with a small pair of sharp scissors. Make sure that the scissors you use are very sharp. Then, cut along the lines you drew onto the felt to get the desired shape. Go back over any edges that you need to clean up. After you finish cutting out the felt, check the edges. Look for any uneven or jagged spots and trim them down. Be careful not to cut too much off or your shape may become distorted. Taping Paper Patterns to Felt Draw or trace a design onto a piece of paper and cut it out. You can use a premade shape or pattern on paper or draw your own. Once you have your design, cut along the edges of it with a sharp pair of scissors.Tip: You can cut just about any shape you like out of felt. Try cutting out hearts, stars, clovers, cats, dogs, flowers, leaves, gingerbread men, or whatever else you want! Tape the pattern onto the felt so that the tape overlaps the edges. Use a few pieces of clear packing tape or scotch tape to attach the paper pattern to the felt. The tape will stick to the paper pattern and the felt so it will stay put while you cut. Using tape is a nice alternative to pinning since there is less chance of poking holes in your felt. Staple the pattern through 2 layers of felt to cut out 2 pieces at once. If you want to cut out 2 pieces of felt using the same pattern at one time, then you can staple the pattern onto 2 layers of felt. You will only need to staple the paper pattern to the felt in 2 to 3 places around the edges to make it stay put. After you cut around the pattern, remove the staples with a staple remover or your fingernails. Make sure to test a small piece of felt first to ensure stapling through it won't damage it. Cut along the edges of the line or design. Once your paper pattern piece is secured to the felt, use a sharp pair of fabric scissors to cut along the edges. Cut slowly and carefully to ensure that you get even, smooth lines. The paper pattern piece will come off as you cut, so make sure to hold it in place with your thumb until you have cut out the whole thing. If you stapled the paper pattern piece through 2 pieces of felt, remove the staples after you finish cutting out the pieces. Ironing on Freezer Paper Patterns Trace your pattern onto the freezer paper. Dispense a piece of freezer paper large enough for the pattern you want to create. Freezer paper is clear, so you can lay the freezer paper over it with the waxy side facing down. Trace the pattern onto the non-waxy side of the freezer paper. You can also draw a design onto the non-waxy side of the freezer paper. Do not cut out the pattern! Leave the freezer paper intact. Place the freezer paper onto the felt. Next, lay the freezer paper on top of your felt with the waxy side facing down. Make sure that the edges of the pattern on the freezer paper fit entirely on the felt. Iron the freezer paper to the felt. Switch on your iron to the lowest setting and let it warm up for about 10 minutes. When it is hot, press it against the freezer paper and move it around the entire pattern using small, circular motions. Do not leave the iron in one place for more than a few seconds. It can shrink wool felt or melt acrylic felt if you leave it in one place for too long. Cut around the edges of the pattern. Once the pattern is secured to the felt, use a sharp pair of fabric scissors to cut along the lines. Cut slowly and carefully to ensure that you don't end up with any jagged edges. After you finish cutting out the felt pieces, grasp the edge of the freezer paper and peel it off of the felt.Tip: You can save your freezer paper pattern pieces and reuse them up to 5 times!
sentences: Drawing Lines onto Felt Draw a line or design on a piece of felt with a disappearing ink marker.
You can use a ruler or other straight edges to make a line across your felt, draw a line or design freehand, or follow around the edges of a pattern to create a design.
A disappearing ink marker will help to ensure that any remaining ink will not be visible on your finished project.
You can purchase disappearing ink at a craft supply store.
Tip: If you don't have a disappearing ink marker, a piece of chalk will also work.
Or, you could use a regular marker and cut inside the lines so you won't have marker on your felt.
Cut along the lines with a small pair of sharp scissors.
Make sure that the scissors you use are very sharp.
Then, cut along the lines you drew onto the felt to get the desired shape.
Go back over any edges that you need to clean up.
After you finish cutting out the felt, check the edges.
Look for any uneven or jagged spots and trim them down.
Be careful not to cut too much off or your shape may become distorted.
Taping Paper Patterns to Felt Draw or trace a design onto a piece of paper and cut it out.
You can use a premade shape or pattern on paper or draw your own.
Once you have your design, cut along the edges of it with a sharp pair of scissors.Tip: You can cut just about any shape you like out of felt.
Try cutting out hearts, stars, clovers, cats, dogs, flowers, leaves, gingerbread men, or whatever else you want!
Tape the pattern onto the felt so that the tape overlaps the edges.
Use a few pieces of clear packing tape or scotch tape to attach the paper pattern to the felt.
The tape will stick to the paper pattern and the felt so it will stay put while you cut.
Using tape is a nice alternative to pinning since there is less chance of poking holes in your felt.
Staple the pattern through 2 layers of felt to cut out 2 pieces at once.
If you want to cut out 2 pieces of felt using the same pattern at one time, then you can staple the pattern onto 2 layers of felt.
You will only need to staple the paper pattern to the felt in 2 to 3 places around the edges to make it stay put.
After you cut around the pattern, remove the staples with a staple remover or your fingernails.
Make sure to test a small piece of felt first to ensure stapling through it won't damage it.
Cut along the edges of the line or design.
Once your paper pattern piece is secured to the felt, use a sharp pair of fabric scissors to cut along the edges.
Cut slowly and carefully to ensure that you get even, smooth lines.
The paper pattern piece will come off as you cut, so make sure to hold it in place with your thumb until you have cut out the whole thing.
If you stapled the paper pattern piece through 2 pieces of felt, remove the staples after you finish cutting out the pieces.
Ironing on Freezer Paper Patterns Trace your pattern onto the freezer paper.
Dispense a piece of freezer paper large enough for the pattern you want to create.
Freezer paper is clear, so you can lay the freezer paper over it with the waxy side facing down.
Trace the pattern onto the non-waxy side of the freezer paper.
You can also draw a design onto the non-waxy side of the freezer paper.
Do not cut out the pattern!
Leave the freezer paper intact.
Place the freezer paper onto the felt.
Next, lay the freezer paper on top of your felt with the waxy side facing down.
Make sure that the edges of the pattern on the freezer paper fit entirely on the felt.
Iron the freezer paper to the felt.
Switch on your iron to the lowest setting and let it warm up for about 10 minutes.
When it is hot, press it against the freezer paper and move it around the entire pattern using small, circular motions.
Do not leave the iron in one place for more than a few seconds.
It can shrink wool felt or melt acrylic felt if you leave it in one place for too long.
Cut around the edges of the pattern.
Once the pattern is secured to the felt, use a sharp pair of fabric scissors to cut along the lines.
Cut slowly and carefully to ensure that you don't end up with any jagged edges.
After you finish cutting out the felt pieces, grasp the edge of the freezer paper and peel it off of the felt.Tip: You can save your freezer paper pattern pieces and reuse them up to 5 times!
